moves.1. d4 d5 2. Bf4 Bf5: Seems, we both know the ropes...
moves.3. e3 Nd7 4. Nc3 e6 5. Nf3 Bd6 6. Bxd6 c: This gives us 2 Queens pawns... Háh!...
moves.8. O-O O-O 9. a4 a6 10. Bxf5: Loses tempo, better first 10. a5 Rc8...
moves.10... Nxf5 11. Qd3 Nh4: The only way, to stir up some dust, and some forced moves...
moves.12. Nxh4 Qxh4 13. Rfe1: 13. f3 Nf6 (or Nb8, e4, Nc6) 14. e4 Rfe8 (too early for Qh5, etc.) 15. exd5 exd5 16. Ne2 is probably better...
moves.13... Rac8 14. e4 dxe4 15. Rxe4 Qg5: I liked this better, then 15. ... Qf6 16. Re3 d5 17. a5!...
moves.16. Re3 d5: Whites second d-pawn comes in handy, now. Better, then 16. ... Qa5 17. Ne4 (b4, Qxb4, Rb1, Qa5, Rxb7, Nf6) Rc6 18. Rg3 Qb6 19. b3!
moves.17. Rg3: 17. a5 Qg6 18. Qxg6 hxg6 19. Ra4 is probably better...
moves.18... Qb4 19. Rd1 Rc6: No good is 19. ... Kh8 20. Rh3 h6 21. g4! Qe7 22. f4!
moves.20... g6 21. Qd2: Any idea's, for white? The main threat now, is Nb6...
moves.21... Rfc8 22. Rd3: 22. f4 Nb6 23. f5 exf5 24. Qh6 R6c7 25. Rh3 f6 26. Qh4 Re8 27. Qxf6 Nxa4...
moves.22... Nb6 23. Qc1: 23. Rb1 a5... Pawn a4 is lost, after all my warnings...
moves.23... Nxa4 24. Nxa4 Qxa4 25. c3 b5 26. Q: 26. Qa1 Qxa1 27. Rxa1 b4, is surely better... Now follows a forced continuation, and black reaches a favourable position...
Slowly, but surely, white is losing control over the situation... 34. g3 Kg7...
moves.35. Kf2 Kg7: Postponing f6, as well as Qa2... Never spoil a good threat...
moves.36... Qb3 37. Kg2 Qa2: I liked this better, then 37. ... f6 38. h3 Kf7... We threaten deadly a3...
moves.40... Qh1: Probably, the winning move... More forced continuations...
moves.44... Qxd2+ 45. Kxd2 Kf5: Without further adue... Even without Kings - only pawns - black will win this... In that case f6...
moves.46. Ke3: 46. Kc3 Ke4... 46. Kd3 h4... This is worse...
moves.47. Kf2 Kh3 48. Kg1 f5: Relentless... White is in Zugzwang, and will lose all of his pawns...

gameName: How to fight the Queens pawn
